examples.title: The Woman Citizen's Wheel of Progress, 1917

description.text: I recreated a 1917 radial map that shows U.S. states' support for legislation of interest to women's suffrage organizations. Good visualizations are truly timeless!

This chart and its later versions were printed in *The Woman Citizen*, an American weekly periodical, as well as flyers in the years leading to the 1920 ratification of the 19th Amendment. You can find the original on the [Claremont Colleges Digital Library's](https://ccdl.claremont.edu/digital/collection/p15831coll5/id/616) website.

[The New York Times's](https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/10/02/us/politics/trump-contact-tracing-covid.html) timeline of events Donald Trump had participated in the week before he tested postive for COVID-19, on a force-directed graph.

The Times didn't include a formal dataset for this story, so I resorted to web scraping. After requesting the HTML file via Axios, I used `d3.select` instead of Cheerio, my go-to scraping library, to obtain the lists of people and meetings, since I was going to use D3 to create the graph anyway. Worked like a charm!
[ProPublica's](https://projects.propublica.org/reopening-america/) map of COVID-19 trajectory across U.S. states, recreated.
To calculate the trend line in each state, I applied linear regression on daily numbers of positive tests per 100,000 people, smoothened into seven-day moving averages, for the past 14 days.
A zoomable timeline of all justices in the U.S. Supreme Court, classified by seat number.

examples.title: Fatal Police Shootings in the U.S.

description.text: An animated version of [The Washington Post's](https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/investigations/police-shootings-database/#js-map) map of all fatal shootings by on-duty police officers from Jan. 1, 2015. Orange flashes indicate new shootings each day.
This was my first attempt at Mapbox, which I absolutely loved!

examples.title: Child Opportunity Index: N.Y.C. & Long Island

description.text: A beeswarm plot tracking the distribution of child-opportunity scores across census tracts in New York City and Long Island.
The [Child Opportunity Index](http://diversitydatakids.org/) measures conditions crucial to child development in the U.S. For this visualization, I used its 2015 scores.
One of the few data visualizations that specifically tracks COVID-19's progress in Vietnam, including a bubble chart and a heat map.

This one was a doozy! Before Vietnam's Minstry of Health release its data of all confirmed cases, I had to compile mine from scratch by going through a *lot* of newspaper articles. Then, from that dataset, using Google Sheets, I created pivot tables detailing daily cases, recoveries and deaths by province, then published them as CSVs that I fetched with D3.
A line-chart matrix showing quarterly house prices, index by the first quarter of 1975, of some non-G7 countries (green) and the U.S. (orange). Can you see traces of the 2008 financial crisis?

I made this one as a tribute to FiveThirtyEight's [matrix visualization](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/trump-approval-ratings/) of Donald Trump's approval ratings compared to other presidents', using `d3.select` with `d3.cross`.

A flow chart outlining the process of creating Nate Silver's [forecast](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-primary-forecast/) for the 2020 Democratic primary, part of the 2020 presidential election in the U.S.

examples.title: The Pink, Minimalist Aesthetic Enticing Hanoi's Millennials

description.text: At the intersection between Hang Bong and Phung Hung streets, there is a bakery whose lavender armchairs look as if they are made from giant ladyfingers. Itâ€™s called Baked by Julie and, since opening last August, has constantly appeared on Instagram thanks to its predominantly pink palette, which is featured on its velour, mitten-shaped armchairs, ceramic teapots and garlanded entrance.

examples.title: For Vietnam's Millennials, Sneakers Reflect American Ideals, Self-Expression and Nostalgia

description.text: My memories of sneakers date back to when I was halfway through 7th grade, when a pair of Chuck Taylor All Star 70â€™s was given to me by my parents to commemorate my good end-of-semester results. The shoes felt awkward, but the sensation of having the same sneakers that the cool kids were wearing was comparable to ecstasy.
